												Detour claims to be an addictive competitive real time strategy game, however, I would say almost none of that is true.There is not much strategy involved aside from 'build roads everywhere you can to block everyone' (Goldmines first so you can afford to keep blocking them), and 'throw explosives at the other players'. It does not have a lot of skill involved aside from who can build the fastest(Which in itself is a matter of being the fastest at clicking). There is very little here that would be competitive, or that would draw anyone wishing to be competitive. There are way better things out there.Addictive? Definitely not. Play it once, maybe twice. Third time with friends and then you´ve seen it all. There is nothing to come back for, and I would say it is severely lacking in replay value.At least it is realtime, and with 4 players throwing explosives it is chaotic so you can at least count that as a plus if you enjoy that sort of thing. For the single player challenges, they do take some effort, though the 'humour' involed in it is certainly not my kind. You are essentially challenged by a bunch of stereotypes which eventually end up teaming up on you. And then it just sort of ends.Detour is a game that sounds good in theory, but just doesn't cut it in practice. Maybe it was a good idea on the idea board that just didn't get fleshed out right, maybe they just lacked the skill or knowledge to make it work. But either way I would recommend against buying Detour - Your time is more valuable than any sale price

												First of all, my original review "Why is this game real?" was read by Senpai Studios, so when the update came out, they told me. So, this is my real review, since the game was fixed and is now functional.5/10 - Functional, but boring. Not good enough to really be a positive review, but not horribly negative.Ok, so the basic gameplay is building roads to get a truck across the map to the other side. At this point, this works well, and has no design flaws. The bridge is a bit confusing to use, and should have adjustable length, but that's just a minor quip. The dynamite and other explosives can be used to destroy the enemy's roads to prevent progress. The dynamite is quite a core part of gameplay, but the larger missile-thing can be used too frequently to be considered balanced. The AI takes advantage of this, and so did my living opponent. This is a bit gamebreaking at times, and needs to be addressed.In terms of "story," since there isn't REALLY much of a story, it was kind of offensive to certain groups. There are jokes making fun of transsexuals, activists, construction workers, the player, cops, and those weird African characters in anime that look like creepy magicians or something. What really bothered me was how they made it very obvious in some, such as the character "Tranny" who has a male-esque voice, and the construction boss guy acts awkward around her. He says he dated her and then he... Cuts off what he's saying. This is just an example of it, but the offensive nature of the NPCs doesn't really detract from the gameplay, though it's a bit irritating. I doubt this is persistent for most people, so this is something to think about.Next, bugs. Even though the menus were supposedly fixed, they are a bit broken after changing the resolution and not restarting. This was a bit weird, especially when I was just confronted about the update, but I figured it out. Then, there's the audio bug. For some reason, when I had just installed the game, there was no music on the menu, while the music played in-game. When I checked the audio settings, both SFX and music were fully muted, but... Well... They weren't. This was fixed by moving the sliders back and forth. The game crashed one time, but that's really to be expected. There were weird connectivity glitches, where I would connect to someone, then they wouldn't be in the game, but I would remain in the lobby. This, and the lack of players, makes multiplayer pretty pointless, especially since it's the purpose of the game.The gameplay, as I explained before, is pretty straightforward. However, it isn't fun, or stressful in a good way. It is bland, whenever the AI doesn't just target you, making it extremely frustrating to try to play, when it isn't so easy it takes no work. I either hard to struggle and lose for no good reason, or I had no competition. In one game, a bit farther along, one AI character didn't even do anything at all, and no, its area wasn't under the FoW at the time.Beyond the broken AI, the gameplay just isn't that fun to begin with. Maybe other people would love DETOUR, but personally, I don't like it. So, if you want to purchase this game, consider what I said, but take it with a grain of salt, and just do what you want to, in terms of buying this game.

DETOUR is an RTS. You build roads to lead your trucks to the finish line while the enemy team does the same. You can disrupt each other with things like missiles and sentry turrets.ControlsSince it's a top down perspective game, you have camera controls which are the WASD keys and mouse to place your buildings and roads. Navigating through different buildables is a hassle. They're categorized into roads, aggressive offensive weapons like missiles, placeable weapons like turrets and truck upgrades. The buildables have each their own hotkeys. It's extremely hectic.SoundsThe music is awful. It's generic and gets really annoying after a while. On top of that, the music usually doesn't fit the mood. While I was given a briefing during the tutorial, the song was intense and felt like it was out of an action movie. When playing a multiplayer free-for-all game, the song reminded me of a calm spring afternoon with its peaceful piano melody.Sound effects were not as terrible. Pretty regular stuff if you ask me. Lifeless without much spice but did its job.GraphicsHorrible. The menus seem to be work in progress. The font choice is bad, text starts from wherever and server browser is a background image of a table with text on top which doesn't even line up with the background. It doesn't help that white is a dominant color and the text is not outlined with a darker color.In-game graphics are simplistic and nothing like the standards today. GUI looks like a mess with garbage visual appearance and placing. Maps are squares in an empty space. Objects are placed on a grid on the square. Effects are simple and nothing looks special. It's dull and unpleasant to look at.BalanceNon-existent. Some maps are not balanced fairly to all players. Some maps are symmetrical and some have three player bases on one side and the last player sits alone in one corner. The AI is either not challenging or already sending its second truck while you're pondering where the second road tile should go to. Everything has a low cooldown so things like missiles can be launched almost constantly. Money doesn't really seem to run out because everything is quite cheap. Though, you can change the income rate and starting cash but I went with defaults.OtherThe broken lobbies. I wasn't sure what was going on first but nothing seems to work properly. It's like that old 1960's TV which you had to give a good whack on the side to make it show clear image. When you select a color, it changes randomly. Sometimes the ready button doesn't work at all. Some game modes can't have more than one player. In a coop mode. Which specifically says "up to three other players". Random players could join spots that I had set as "Friends only", "Invite only" and "Closed". There are four gamemodes. I only had the chance to play one. Free-For-All.In conclusion, it's a small RTS with an interesting idea but it feels like it wasn't finished. Barely functioning multiplayer options, generic music, low standard graphics and unbalanced gameplay. It's supposed to be a hectic game and that it is, I must give credit. The game is extremely cheap from the sales but I don't think it was really worth the time or money.I don't recommend DETOUR.

DETOUR is a difficult game to review, it has some excellent aspects but also a number of flaws that need addressing. Again, due-to the lack of a "Mixed" option for recommendations, I'll ultimately go for "Yes" as the good features of this game outweigh the bad ones. DETOUR is a refreshing addition to the RTS genre, the goal is to escort a certain number of trucks to the opposite end of the map by any means necessary. Construct a safe passage overcoming all kinds of obstacles, including enemy players doing anything they can to hinder your progress at the same time. A nice and simple concept that plays out fairly well once you get the hang of things. The game is fun in short bursts, things can get challenging and hectic quite quickly depending on the number of players on the map at hand, this makes for some great gameplay from time to time, but can be just as frustrating too. Micromanagement is key.For me the number one problem with DETOUR is the interface, which is one of the most (if not THE most) important aspect of any RTS game. Things are simply not clear enough, and when the gameplay is hectic and there is so much going on at once, there is little time to spend glaring at the icons and making sure you are selecting and building the correct things, it's not uncommon to end up building something completely different to what you were actually aiming for because icons are small, unclear and similar-looking. The Missiles for example are the main culprit here. This could be improved upon a lot, even simply by making the icons larger, clearer and adding some visible text on the images themselves, the hotkeys could also use some revision as they feel all over the place right now.There isn't much singleplayer content in DETOUR either as of the moment, and with so few people playing online, you'll find that you'll run out of things to do relatively quickly. It's a shame that the online lobbies are empty all of the while because this games full potential probably lies within facing off against human opponents instead of the predictable AI. So, do I recommend DETOUR? Yes, but it barely makes it as a positive review. The game is interesting and refreshing enough for me to recommend to any fans of the RTS genre, despite the clunky and confusing interface. Don't jump into DETOUR expecting one of the best games ever made, because it's far from it, but I'd say it's worth trying at least once. If you can round up some friends to play this game with you, you'll definitely have a better time with it than you will on the singleplayer missions, which are decent as tutorial stages at least.

												DETOUR is an RTS game which focuses around building your highways and destroying your enemies' highways before they're able to send any of their delivery trucks. The game is pretty okay, first thing I've noticed it the nice interactive menu which changes with some graphic changes but also shakes when trucks pass by. The disappointment however was seeing how low the System Requirements were, but it still lagged. I had to switch to system cursor as it was laggy and the graphics options were scarce to begin with. I also noticed a lot of lag spikes when bombs were launched. The first missions were extremely easy and most of the times there's a loophole around them. Either be it just using bombs and continuously sending your trucks, or dynamiting the enemy's road. It's pretty simple. But then I reached a point where I got constantly nuked, which was really frustrating. The AI seems to have it much easier and the difficulties don't scale too well. Graphically speaking it's "okay" for an RTS, but the character heads that speak looks too childish and the sound the main person keeps making is pretty annoying. I can't complain much about the music, though. The UI however is somewhat confusing and takes time to get used to where is which item, making you lose essential time and potentially the match as well. Another thing to mention is the way you select items and the way you get the description should be reworked. I'd expect hovering over the item with my mouse gives me details and pressing on it will select it, but it works otherwise which disappoints me because it's really hard to understand what the item is by looking at it. I haven't noticed any bugs except for where it doesn't simply allow me to build somewhere and it doesn't specify why. All in all, if you're fan of RTS you can try this one out as it offers kind of a twist to the genre but there are better titles out there. Unless you're on a really tight budget as it gets cheap on sale. I wouldn't, however, recommend it at full price.>I'd give it a 7/10>Pros: Lots of levels, the objectives and the way the game functions are different than the usual,  multiplayer, cards and achievements, it has potential to be a good game.>Cons: Needs a rework on the UI, needs more optimization, better AI and/or fix the loopholes allowing for easy level clearing, annoying voicing.

												Neat idea with poor execution. This game could be a lot of fun, but I'm still trying to figure out if the developers have even tried playing the game. The interface is clunky. Hot keys change your selection but don't take action. For instance you use WASD to move your view around the map and one of the most important tools, sensor sweep, is mapped to F2. Makes sense - your fingers are already in that general vicinty, however pressing F2 doesn't do the sensor sweep, it just makes the sensor sweep the selected action. You then have to hit the enter key which is clear across the keyboard from F2. For single player, the first real mission after training is, as far as i can tell, unbeatable. AI opponents with no truck goals will target you, even if you also have no goals, over the AI opponent who is about to win. I tried several different strategies to foil the AI, including not completing my final road segment until a truck just needs that last segment; still no good. Learned all of the hot keys (such as they are) and the speedup still wasn't enough. I outspend all of the AIs, I nuke the AIs whenever I can... doesn't matter. There are 3 of them and one of you. There are a bunch more single player missions after that, but I've not seen them. The single player is just broken.For multiplayer... my son and I played a few games, and while it was a little fun, the turret balance is completely off. Offensive turrets fire too fast and have too much health. They aren't taken out with a nuke and they can destroy roads as fast as you can build them. Defensive turrets are way too weak to be effective and the game quickly becomes an offensive turret race. It's cute for a little while, but quickly becomes boring.I don't feel ripped off, I had about 1 hour of fun and the game was incredibly inexpensive; I am disappointed that a laundry list of seemingly simple and obvious improvements are still missing that could make this a reasonably fun game.

												Take on the brutal world of transport trucking. Will you be able to take on your foes and make sure that your routes stay intact so that your trucks can meet their quota? Well that's what it takes in the game Detour, by Sandswept Studios. This real-time strategy game will have you on the edge of your seat trying to keep up with what is going on in the game as well as devising new plans to meet your goal.Graphically this game isn't at the top of the food chain, but there's enough here to make you feel pulled into the game. Each level is on a grid based system and in those grids you can find opponent's roads, hills, mountains, protestors, rubble, buildings and more. You'll also notice that in every level there is one corner of the grid that has a checked flag pattern, that's your ultimate goal.So lets get into what it is about this game, well there's definitely a good number of single player scenarios that you can take on, each one, of course, ramping up in difficulty, however, there were definitely some of the later stages that I breezed through in comparision to earlier ones. Now that might be because I got used to the flow of the game or perhaps luck. Either way I definitely was relieved when after a hard level I was able to breeze through the next one.This is definitely an interesting game, but it definitely has some flaws and quirks. The first one has to do with the lack of voice acting, look I understand not everyone has the budget to do that, but at the same time if you're going to have a "Sims" voice do SOME of the dialogue, you're going to need it to do ALL of the dialogue. It was really odd when the first speech bubble has random yammering (aka Sims talk) and then the very next one greets you with silence.Now as I stated this game is challenging, but the issue that I have is that the challenge, for me was more so about trying to control the game, and not so much playing the game. You see developers definitely thought in depth about giving the player many different options to play around with in the game, the only issue is that getting to them is a PAIN. Here's the deal, you have four different sections of choices that you can play around with, each has at least 3 different options in it. Think of it as a menu bar. The problem is that if you try to go the mouse scroll wheel route not only is the y-axis flipped but scrolling will not only cause you to select each section but each choice within that section before going to the next section. There is an alternative, you can use the keyboard, which once again I found cumbersome. You see you're going to be using WASD to move around the grid to see what all there is to see, but you can use the arrow keys to select the sections, this time it will just select the sections, but once again the y-axis is flipped, which is beyond disorienting. Here's the deal every time I have to make a decision, especially if I have to change sections, I have to take myself out of the game and try to figure out how the hell I'm going to do what I need to do, and that takes away from what should be my main focus, the actual game. Perhaps they should have found a simpler way of making choices, or maybe remove some of those choices, but as of right now the controls are so cumbersome that this game isn't fun.There's definitely something there, and you definitely need to bring your A game to really do well in this game, but with such a barrier as your choice of selections in the game and the inability to easily make choices, this game might need to be left alone for the time being. This game gets a 6.1 out of 10.

												While this isn't a sort of game I expect to find on Steam, I was somewhat surprised at how much I enjoyed playing DETOUR.Sempai Studios had given me a free key (thank you) and while it took me a while to get around to playing it (sorry!) this ended up being a remedy to what ended up being a particularly painful recovery day.DETOUR reminds me a lot of the PC board games I used to play as a 90s little girl when I wasn't quite into bigger gaming. You've got the main goal (reach the end) and you have to go up against the AI with varying levels of difficulty. It's not difficult in theory. The farther you progress, the more power ups you earn. Building and power ups take points. Patience is rewarded but patience can be what causes your bitter defeat.You're not going to be too entirely impressed with the artwork of the characters you meet in this game. The characters are very cartoony in style, but for something I'd call a time management board game, I don't find that part too important. You might. You need to know this. The actual playing field looks like your average grid filled with general pixelated grass, cityscape, rubble, etc. It's not entirely impressive. It's there. It's your playing field and it's enough for me.Personally, I had a little bit of issue with relying on my mouse so there seemed to be something slowing me down with clicking on things. I'm not sure if it was because I'm unused to seeing an orange cone as my pointer or if there were actual mouse problems. I ended up being pretty happy to use the keyboard when I could. Clicking wasn't always my friend in this game.Otherwise, I really enjoyed myself. The games are very short to play and they are made so that a lot of action happens at once. There are a few unique personalities to deal with, but otherwise there's not really much of a story there. It's more like a bland, shell of a story. It's more like the sort of stories you're expecting from time management games you download to kill an hour from a certain website that has a lot of HOGs. You get a few laughs from some of the text and you proceed to simply play the game. That's how it works.Some players may find this boring and stop after the first part of the game, as yes, the easy section of the game is easy to blow through. You could purchase this for friends during the Summer Sale and use this just for playing against friends. This is a good choice if you're not into anything with gore (though most of us are, guilty as charged). Then again, those of us who are board game addicts (also guilty as charged) might enjoy this, too.Of course then there's taking joy in finding ways to completely obliterate your opponent and dominate the field so they can't build. Being that sadistic is a sort of joy that comes from the game, as is the quick win or the slow and agonizing type of defeat. It's not hard to win, it's just the matter of how to get there. You'll learn, but it's about thinking quickly and ensuring there will be a victory.It's a game I'll likely revisit from time to time because you can pick it up and put it down. Though I'd rather give this a sort of lukewarm rating, what tips it over is I did like it and I'll certainly be playing during my "I AM JUST SO BORED!" between treatments and napping.Your handicap and health issues: The graphics can get a little bit bright and sometimes blink. I've got a mild headache after playing, but nothing too serious. Caution. Danger Will Robinson.

-Quick Review-DETOUR is a real-time highway-simulator strategy-game developed by Sandswept Studios. The objective can be summed up as “get this truck across the finish line, on the other side of the map”. DETOUR gets increasingly complex with weapons, buildings, and opposing AI or Human Players (in Multiplayer).


For the review! 
A Screenshot of DETOUR
By: Atratzu




-Detailed breakdown review-Story: You work for a construction company over seen by not-bob-the-builder. I can't actually remember that guys name, I just know he sure looked like bob the builder, but wasn't friendly at all.


Bob-the-not-builder 
Community Created Artwork for DETOUR
By: Atratzu

			This guy isn't Creasely or whatever he said his name was. I Atratzu, hereby dub thee "Bob-the-not-builder".		


As you progress through the game you are faced with different NPC's who are competing with you to get their trucks across the finish line. Sometimes they're all facing the same direction, other times you're pitted head-to-head with 3 NPC's against you.Gameplay: DETOUR itself starts out very simple, and attempts to teach you the basic concepts as you play through, although the explanations are quite wordy and I concluded “I'll learn the hard way, I don't feel like reading”. (Yes, yes, shame on me. I didn't feel like dealing with Bob-the-not-builder's putting me down even though I did nothing but succeed for the company! *spit*)As in most real-time strategy games, you reach a point where you can no longer click fast enough to compete, so you need to learn the keyboard shortcuts to keep up with the other players/AI. Unfortunately the keyboard short cuts are 1234567890 and some of the “F1-F2-F3-etc.” keys.There are four categories of “build-able” objects; Roads, Trucks, Weapons, and Buildings. Roads are are used to cross different map terrain. Various truck upgrades can be purchased to speed up or defend your trucks. Weapons can be used to destroy, or impede other players/AI progress. And Buildings are limited but you can build ground turrets, air turrets, satellites and more.Multiplayer can be challenging and fun, however getting to that point is a whole new kind of headache. Naturally there are connection problems depending on the physical location of the person you're playing with, but just trying to CONNECT to that persons game can take nearly five minutes. And then sometimes you might get disconnected from that persons game.


You see a lot of this.... 
A Screenshot of DETOUR
By: Atratzu




Not to mention you need to probably arrange a game with a friend, since there aren't enough people playing the game that you can just drop in and play with a random person.Achievements: Now we come to my biggest complaint about this game... the achievements are painfully tedious. There are 28 achievements in DETOUR. After beating the game for the first time I had literally 4 achievements.Most of the achievements in DETOUR are actually exclusively unlocked in multiplayer mode. And none of them are quick unlocks, you need to coordinate with 3 other people for some achievements, but a handful of achievements can be unlocked with just another person (1 vs 1 matches).Price: DETOUR is priced at $4.99, for an indie game that's a pretty fair price. I personally like to spend one hour in game for every dollar, that will easily show up on my game time, because... ...unfortunately connecting to a 4 player game requires about five minutes of restarting and reconnecting DETOUR.The single player campaign will take about an hour or two, depending on how good you are at strategy games.Conclusion: Story: irrelevant – I didn't feel like reading the day I did the campaign. A tiny note in my defense; a game should make you WANT to know more about the story, and this game failed in that aspect. Gameplay: the core mechanics were mostly solid, but there were graphical errors, and multiplayer connection problems. Achievements: Agonizingly long to work on these and un-soloable. Not an easy 100% completion game. Price: the price is a little high for how much time the average player will spend on the game.All in all, DETOUR has a number of flaws and I haven't particularly enjoyed playing it. That probably means most “normal” people won't like playing it. However if you're looking for a game to play with a friend, this will give you several hours of entertainment, and even more hours of connection problems.I recommend this game to Indie-Game Supporters, Strategy-game-fans, and achievers who aren't daunted by several hours of coordinating with others to obtain 100% completion.------Edits and updates------Edit/Update August 24, 2015:Formatting Updates/Adjustments

												Detour is a race to the finish, strategy game where you play as a member of the Hard Head Construction Co, whose job it is to build a road from the player factory on the bottom end of the gameboard, all the way to the other end of the gameboard. This road can be constructed as a standard road, mountain tunnel, and bridge over water. Sounds simple enough; However there are multiple obstacles both environmental as well as Computer opponent created, which work against you. From Marshlands where protesters can be bribed to block, Boulders you need to destroy, Rivers to cross and mountains to tunnel through, Computer players destroying your roads and more, Detour offers an interesting challenge. Oh, did I forget? You also have tolet loose your fleet of factory trucks and get them to safety before your opponent, otherwise you are out of a job. Detours might seem easy and simplistic, but as you progress it becomes more challenging, with a computer AI that knows right where to hurt you. Detour offers you the chance to play through 9 tutorial missions, with progressive difficulty, teaching you how to navigate various obstacles and use various tools such as road nails, dynamite, and truck speed upgrades to your advantage. All in all, even though the game comes off as simple, it grows on you and can be challenging the further you progress. Pick it up, give it a try.

Review - DETOUR"I never knew road-building would be this challenging!"DETOUR is an RTS game where your main goal is to build a road such that you'll be able to send enough trucks to the other side of the map but there's a catch, you're not the only one aiming for that goal. The player will be playing against AI players and yeah, they'll do anything to stop each other from reaching the other side of the map whether they need to use dynamites, bombs or even those EMP missiles. DETOUR is a very challenging game since building a road to the other side won't be a stroll around the park. Though you'll all have the same upgrades but still, it'll require strategic planning and timing especially that resources are very scarce when all hell has broken loose. There will be times that you'll need to be cunning like having a decoy road while making a secret route or go for a straight-forward approach, and immediately aim for the other side or you could even go for a destructive approach where you'll save up your resources and wait for your opponents to finish making their roads and then destroy them to smithereens while stacking your road for the win. It's a strategy of your choice.I recommend this game for those who are looking for a cheap yet challenging game. The graphics and sound effects are simple but the gameplay itself can gob about 2-3 hours of your time. The game also features multiplayer mode. And just a little advice for new players, if you're playing with your friends on multiplayer mode, the large bomb weapon can end a lot of friendships.My Personal Rating:Graphics: 6/10Music: 7/10Gameplay: 8/10Overall: 7.0

												Disclaimer: I was generously given a free copy of Detour with the understanding that I was expected to review the title after spending some time with it.Detour is a puzzle game which tasks you with creating a safe route for a truck to pass through a hostile city.Now the bad part. This game runs atrociously. The first thing that struck me when starting up the game for the first time is the inexcusable amount of latency when using the software cursor. The delay between my mouse movement and the cursors response on the screen varied anywhere from 0.5 to (not exaggerating) 2.5 seconds! If you’re really desperate to play Detour, your first priority should be to enable Hardware Cursor in the options menu. Following the debacle with the laggy mouse, I noticed there were a fair few grammatical issues with the level selection text. Typically with low budget/hobby games I sort of just overlook this, especially when the narrative is, for all intents and purposes, irrelevant to the actual gameplay. Unfortunately, after seeing the issues with the cursor, these errors were much more eye catching and set a precedent in my mind that this was either shoddily put together or unnecessarily rushed to release. Then I began the campaign. I actually quit midway through the first level just to activate Steams’ FPS counter and boot up Fraps to confirm my suspicions: this isometric mobile-port style puzzle game was running at 16 FPS on a GTX 680 and an overclocked i7-2600k. I suffered on through a handful more levels just to know what the game was trying to be, and as intriguing as the concept may be, the performance of this game is just abysmal.

												Detour is an odd game. First off, it’s based around multiplayer, but unless you have played through the first couple of single player missions, you have no idea what’s going on. Another thing I noticed right off was the framerate. On a computer with a Core i5 processor, 16 GB of RAM, and a GPU with 2 GB of RAM of its own, I was getting 16 frames per second. On a computer that’s about 4 times the system requirements! However, once the game started, it didn’t disappoint. While the graphics aren’t the best, especially running at 16 frames per second on the lowest settings, the gameplay was fantastic. The goal of the game is to get a certain number of trucks from your factory to the other side of the map using roads and tunnels. However, your opponent can try to stop you through many methods. One of these is by bribing the police to stop your trucks. After getting sufficiently angry, retaliation can be had by bombing your fellow opponent off of the face of the earth. Mad at the fog of war? No problem! Just run a scan! Don’t want to be scanned? Jam the signal! Don’t want your opponents getting across wetlands? Just fund the local conservation foundation! The fun in this game truly lies in the simplicity of the gameplay, but the complexity the game can take on when played by two skilled players.After all this, I give this game a thumbs up. It may not be the most visually appealing, but it’s all it set out to be: a good RTS based around semi trucks. I never thought I’d ever type that last sentence, but there it is. Anything can happen.

												Detour is a real-time strategy game where your goal is to get three trucks from your base to the opposite side of the map. Watch out for dynamite that destroys road, missiles that take out your trucks, and other hazards that others may send at you.It's kind of an interesting premise, that leads to some interesting, fast-paced gameplay. That said, when there were four players desparately fighting for the middle ground, it was incredibly hard to figure out what was going on at any given time. I'd be repairing roads in one part the map while the other half was getting shredded by the AI. Half the time, the bridges and tunnels didn't work as I expected, and I didn't realize my roads weren't connecting.Sadly, this ends up as an amateur attempt at a strategy game. There's a good idea here, but it's not well-designed, and as a result, really isn't all that fun and not terribly engaging for fans of strategy. It seems like it would be mildly entertaining as a dumb multiplayer game, since the frantic action could make some fun moments with friends, but I think that's about the only value you'll find here. If this looks interesting, check out Sid Meier's Railroads!, which is buggy and flawed but much more fun.

												This is a game that expands greatly in the amount of ways you can beat your opponent, and is a decent game to play if you just want to practice strategies for other games in general. Overall it is a nice game to play a round of with friends just to try new things and challenge yourself, but the initial game itself doesn't hold much strategy to it from there.
